tit.e: Hyakki yako (Night Parade of One Hundred Demons)
Hyakki yako (Night Parade of One Hundred Demons)
Hyakki yako (Night Parade of One Hundred Demons)

sen.j: 百鬼夜行（ひゃっきやぎょう、ひゃっきやこう）とは、説話などに登場する深夜の町を集団で徘徊する鬼や妖怪の群れ及びその行進のこと。
sen.e: Hyakki yagyo, or hyakki yako (Night Parade of One Hundred Demons) means a troop of demons and monsters wandering in a group in a city in the middle of the night and their parade, appearing in setsuwa (anecdotes).

Hyakki yagyo, or hyakki yako (Night Parade of One Hundred Demons) are stories about troops of demons and monsters wandering in a group in a city in the middle of the night in a parade, appearing in setsuwa (anecdotes).
sen.cmt: "Means"-"is". "And their"-"in a". Added "are stories about" to make the meaning a little clearer.
sen.e: Hyakki yagyo, or hyakki yako (Night Parade of One Hundred Demons) are stories about troops of demons and monsters wandering in a group in a city in the middle of the night in a parade, appearing in setsuwa (anecdotes).

sen.j: 説話に登場する異形の集団で、『百鬼夜行にあった』という表現をする。
sen.e: They are a group of strange-looking demons appearing in setsuwa (anecdotes), which use the expression "(someone) came across a hyakki yako".
They are a group of strange-looking demons appearing in setsuwa (anecdotes), which use the expression "(someone) came across a hyakki yako".
They are a group of strange-looking demons appearing in setsuwa (anecdotes), which use the expression "(someone) came across a hyakki yako."

sen.j: 読経することにより難を逃れた話や、読経しているうちに朝日が昇ったところで鬼たちが逃げたり、いなくなったりする話が一般的で、仏の功徳を説く話である
sen.e: Stories where one escapes from danger by chanting sutras, or stories where the sun rises while one is chanting sutras and the demons run away or disappear are common, and they are stories preaching the benefits of the Buddha.

Stories where one escapes from danger by chanting sutras, or stories where the sun rises while one is chanting sutras and the demons run away or disappear are common, and they are stories preaching the benefits of the Buddha.

Stories where one escapes from danger by chanting sutras, or stories where the sun rises while one is chanting sutras and the demons run away or disappear are common, and they are stories preaching the benefits of the Buddha.

sen.j: 古典の百科全書『拾芥抄』によれば、正月、2月子日、3月・4月午日、5月・6月巳日、7月・8月戌日、9月・10月未日、11月・12月辰日は百鬼夜行が出現する「百鬼夜行日」であり、百鬼夜行に出遭うと死んでしまうといわれたため、これらの日には夜の外出を控えたという。
sen.e: According to the classical encyclopedia "Shukaisho", 'Hyakki-yako days', the days when a hyakki yako appears, were on the New Year, the day of the Rat in February, the day of the Horse in March and April, the day of the Snake in May and June, the day of the Dog in July and August, the day of the Ram in September and October, and the day of the Dragon in November and December, so people used to avoid going out at night on those days because it was said that they would die if they came across a hyakki yako.

According to the classical encyclopedia Shukaisho, 'Hyakki-yako days', the days when a hyakki yako appears, were on the New Year, the day of the Rat in February, the day of the Horse in March and April, the day of the Snake in May and June, the day of the Dog in July and August, the day of the Ram in September and October, and the day of the Dragon in November and December, so people used to avoid going out at night on those days because it was said that they would die if they came across a hyakki yako.

According to the classical encyclopedia "Shukaisho," 'Hyakki-yako days,' the days when a hyakki yako appears, were on the New Year, the day of the Rat in February, the day of the Horse in March and April, the day of the Snake in May and June, the day of the Dog in July and August, the day of the Ram in September and October, and the day of the Dragon in November and December (old calendar), so people used to avoid going out at night on those days because it was said that they would die if they came across a hyakki yako.

sen.j: また同じく『拾芥抄』によると、「カタシハヤ、エカセニクリニ、タメルサケ、テエヒ、アシエヒ、ワレシコニケリ」と呪文を唱えると、百鬼夜行の害を避けられるという。
sen.e: "Shukaisho" also says that if people chant the spell 'katashihaya, ekasenikurini, tamerusake, teehi, ashiehi, waresikonikeri', they can avoid harm from a hyakki yako.
sen.cmt: 呪文の意味について調べてみたのですが、未だに不明のようでしたので、現代日本語での読みをローマ字表記にしました。
sen.e: Shukaisho also says that if people chant the spell 'katashihaya, ekasenikurini, tamerusake, teehi, ashiehi, waresikonikeri', they can avoid harm from a hyakki yako.
"Shukaisho" also says that if people chant the spell 'katashihaya, ekasenikurini, tamerusake, teehi, ashiehi, waresikonikeri', they can avoid harm from a hyakki yako.

sen.j: ある修行僧が摂津国の竜泉寺で出遭った100もの鬼の集団。
sen.e: A group of 100 demons that a novice monk came across at Ryusen-ji Temple in Settsu Province.
A group of 100 demons that a novice monk came across at Ryusen-ji Temple in Settsu Province.
A group of 100 demons that a novice monk came across at Ryusen-ji Temple in Settsu Province.

sen.j: 諸行無常を詠じながら大路を通った、馬頭の鬼の話
sen.e: A story of demons with the heads of horses that were crossing an avenue while reciting sutras about the impermanence of all things.
sen.cmt: 「諸行無常を詠ず」は、調べたところ、お経を唱えていました[参考：http://www.kyotohyakki.com/web_0317/2008%20kasou.html]
sen.e: A story of demons with the heads of horses that were crossing an avenue while reciting sutras about the impermanence of all things.
A story of demons with the heads of horses that were crossing an avenue while reciting sutras about the impermanence of all things.

sen.j: 今昔物語集
sen.e: Konjaku Monogatari Shu (The Collection of Tales of Times Now Past)
Konjaku Monogatari Shu (The Collection of Tales of Times Now Past)
Konjaku Monogatari Shu (The Collection of Tales of Times Now Past)

sen.j: 貞観 (日本)年間（859～877）、右大臣藤原良相の長男、大納言左大将藤原常行が愛人のもとへ行く途中、美福門周辺で東大宮大路の方から歩いてくる100人ほどの鬼の集団に遭遇。
sen.e: During the Jogan era (Japan, 859～877), when Major Counselor and General of the Left FUJIWARA no Tsuneyuki, the oldest son of Minister of the Right FUJIWARA no Yoshimi, was on his way to his mistress, he came across about 100 demons in a group walking from Higashi Omiya Oji near the Bifukumon Gate.

During the Jogan era (Japan, 859～877), when Major Counselor and General of the Left FUJIWARA no Tsuneyuki, the oldest son of Minister of the Right FUJIWARA no Yoshimi, was on his way to his mistress, he came across about 100 demons in a group walking from Higashi Omiya Oji near the Bifukumon Gate.

During the Jogan era (Japan, 859 - 877), when Dainagon (chief councilor of state) and General of the Left FUJIWARA no Tsuneyuki, the oldest son of Udaijin (Minister of the Right) FUJIWARA no Yoshimi, was on his way to his mistress, he came across about 100 demons in a group walking from Higashi Omiya Oji near the Bifukumon Gate.
sen.cmt: ～→-"Minister of the Right"→"Udaijin (Minister of the Right)"に変更しました。"Major Counselor"→"Dainagon (chief councilor of state)"に変更しました。

sen.j: 常行の乳母が阿闍梨に書いてもらった尊勝仏頂陀羅尼を縫いこんであった服を着ていたので、これに気がついた鬼たちは逃げていった。
sen.e: As he was wearing clothes into which his menoto (wet nurse) had sewn the Buddha Head spell she had had an Ajari (high priest) write, the demons noticed it and ran away.
As he was wearing clothes into which his menoto (wet nurse) had sewn the Buddha Head spell she had had an Ajari (high priest) write, the demons noticed it and ran away.
As he was wearing clothes into which his menoto (wet nurse) had sewn the Buddha Head spell she had had an Ajari (high priest) write, the demons noticed it and ran away.

sen.j: 天暦10年（956）に藤原師輔が遭遇したもの。
sen.e: The one that FUJIWARA no Morosuke came across in 956.
The one that FUJIWARA no Morosuke came across in 956.
The one that FUJIWARA no Morosuke came across in 956.

sen.j: 蘇我入鹿を先頭に、蘇我馬子、蘇我倉山田石川麻呂、山背大兄王、大津皇子、山辺皇女など藤原氏を恨んで死んだ者たちの行列。
sen.e: A parade by those who died with a grudge against the Fujiwara clan--SOGA no Iruka at the head of the parade, then SOGA no Umako, SOGA no Kurayamada Ishikawa Maro, YAMASHIRO no Oe no O, Prince Otsu, Princess Yamanobe, etc.

tit.j: 百鬼夜行を描いた作品

sen.j: 百鬼夜行絵巻(ひゃっきやぎょうえまき)
sen.e: Hyakki yagyo emaki (Hyakki yagyo picture scroll)
Hyakki yagyo emaki (Hyakki yagyo picture scroll)
Hyakki yagyo emaki (Hyakki yagyo picture scroll)

sen.j: 16世紀の室町時代に作られた絵巻。
sen.e: It is a picture scroll made in the Muromachi period in the 16 century.
It is a picture scroll made in the Muromachi period in the 16 century.
It is a picture scroll made in the Muromachi period in the 16 century.

sen.j: 説話に登場する百鬼夜行を題材としながらも、描かれているのは古い器物が変じて怪となる、いわゆる付喪神で、現在の百鬼夜行とは異なる。
sen.e: Although it made the hyakki yako appearing in setsuwa the subject matter, because it depicts the so-called "tsukumogami", old utensils turned to monsters, it is different from the present meaning of hyakki yako.

Although it made the hyakki yako appearing in setsuwa the subject matter, because it depicts the so-called "tsukumogami", old utensils turned to monsters, it is different from the present meaning of hyakki yako.

sen.j: 太陽の出現で終わっている。

sen.j: 鳥山石燕の作品で百鬼夜行絵巻や、その他の作品に登場する妖怪たちを分類し名付け、辞典化したもの。
sen.e: It is the work of Sekien TORIYAMA, who categorized monsters appearing in the Hyakki yagyo emaki and other works, named them and made a dictionary of them.
It is the work of Sekien TORIYAMA, who categorized monsters appearing in the Hyakki yagyo emaki and other works, named them and made a dictionary of them.
